channel.title: HowTo: Configure SVN+SSH with Subclipse on Windows
channel.description: Problem: Use ssh tunnelling to access a Subversion repository using SSH tunneling (i.e. with a subversion repository url of svn+ssh://myservername/myrepo) using the Subclipse subversion integration with Eclipse. I tried various things and used each of the three interfaces for configuring...
channel.dc:creator: Martin

item.title: Comment by Sam Judson+00:00
item.description:
Hi Martin
Just saw the post about your new job in Illinois - congrats.
Sam (from BT)
item.dc:creator: Sam Judson

item.title: Comment by Jez+00:00
item.description: What the hell are you on about? :)
item.dc:creator: Jez

item.title: Comment by John Carney+00:00
item.description:
I tried the above and it didn't work. What worked for me was editing the Subversion config file, which is at C:\Documents and Settings\\Application Data\Subversion\config.
It's an INI-style file, uncomment the line reading [tunnels] and add the following line underneath it: ssh = C:\Program Files\TortoiseSVN\bin\TortoisePlink.exe
Obviously you will need to modify the line if you have installed TortoiseSVN somewhere else.
item.dc:creator: John Carney

item.title: Comment by Christopher Yu+00:00
item.description:
I tried this method, but still had to enter my password on EACH update.
http://docs.codehaus.org/display/CASTOR/SVN+Access+from+Eclipse+Using+Subclipse
worked for me and does NOT require ANY third part applications.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Yu

item.title: Comment by Dust+00:00
item.description: Sweet, thanks for the info. I had a similar problem with AnkhSVN and Visual Studio 2005, and the environment variable fixed it.
item.dc:creator: Dust

item.title: Comment by K123+00:00
item.description:
# Install Subclipse plugin from http://subclipse.tigris.org/ if you have not already installed it.
If you have to enter password you many multiple times like I did (note I have cygwin installed) then follow the below instruction. Might work for you.
# In Eclipse, under Windows --> Preferences --> Team --> SVN --> SVN interface: make sure you have selected JavaSVN.
Now i only have to enter my password once, no errors
item.dc:creator: K123

item.title: Comment by anonymous+00:00
item.description: Nice! Thanks for the excellent instructions. I did the optional victory jig.
item.dc:creator: anonymous

item.title: Comment by Louis+00:00
item.description: Thanks for the tip! For others having problems, I had to generate the key on my server, then use puttygen to convert it to .ppk format (otherwise pageant complains about the OPEN-SSH file type).
item.dc:creator: Louis

item.title: Comment by Dmitry Makhno+00:00
item.description: Cross link to this post added here: http://confluence.public.thoughtworks.org/display/CCNET/Subversion+Source+Control+Block
item.dc:creator: Dmitry Makhno

item.title: Comment by Stephen Mulcahy+00:00
item.description:
Hi Martin,
I've just been dabbling with Subclipse and was having problems with svn+ssh repositories .. your instructions here worked a treat to get things going.
Thanks,
-stephen
item.dc:creator: Stephen Mulcahy

item.title: Comment by Jason McVetta+00:00
item.description:
I used PuTTY's "plink" component -- which I already had installed in C:\opt -- instead of installing TortoiseSVN. It was pretty easy, and it works seamlessly with the Pageant authentication agent too:
[tunnels] ssh = c:\\opt\\plink.exe
item.dc:creator: Jason McVetta

item.title: Comment by Martin Woodward+00:00
item.description:
Hi Jason,
The advantage of the plink that comes with TortoiseSVN is that it doen't fire up a command shell when run. In the version of Plink that I had with my Putty installation it kept firing up a command window when connecting - while I was able to get that window to run minimized, it was still annoying for me.
Did you not have that problem? I'm wondering if the Putty plink has changed recently?
M.
item.dc:creator: Martin Woodward

item.title: Comment by Blaine Simpson+00:00
item.description:
All of this configuration work, other than generating keys, is unnecessary.
Just use the Pure Java SSH provider instead of the JNI one. Just like with JDBC drivers, if a pure Java product will do what you want, everything is much easier.
I've helped people use Svn with Eclipse for years, and the pure driver ssh providers are always better.
item.dc:creator: Blaine Simpson

item.title: Comment by Glen Mazza+00:00
item.description: Thanks for taking the time to post this. This fixed the Subclipse problem I was having.
item.dc:creator: Glen Mazza

item.title: Comment by Mingyan+00:00
item.description: This is the best discussion on the tunnel error about svn. The 'pure java' solution works for me. What I did is: in Eclipse, Windows->Preferences->Team->SVN->svn interfaces, choose SVNKIT(pure java) instead of the default JavaHL (JNI). Thank you all.
item.dc:creator: Mingyan

item.dc:creator: abhishek gupta

item.title: Comment by Dave+00:00
item.description: Thanks Martin. This solution worked for me. I recently started seeing the 2 messages: - "The system cannot find the file specified..." - "Can't create tunnel..." Which I had never seen before. And SVN was working fine. I thought I had set it to use the pure Java drivers. So, I checked and found that I only had one choice (JNI). And, until I came across your fix. Subclipse would not work. I even tried Revert-Reinstall. -Dave
item.dc:creator: Dave

item.title: Comment by James+00:00
item.description: Thanks for that, it worked a treat first go!
item.dc:creator: James

item.title: Comment by ja+00:00
item.description:
To save your password set this in your Windows Env Variables:
Variable name: SVN_SSH Variable value: C:\\Program Files\\TortoiseSVN\\bin\\TortoisePlink.exe -l username -pw password
;)
item.dc:creator: ja

u rock man

had to use javaHL and u made my day
plink rocks
i was annoyed to see popups with cygwin's ssh

item.title: Comment by justinfaulkner.myopenid.com+00:00
item.description:
All I had to do was Go to Window->Preferences->Team->SVN->SVN Interface and switch to SVNKit, then the problem fixed itself.
Thanks for the great post (that although wasn't quite the fix for me, it helped me find a solution that worked for me in the comments).
item.dc:creator: justinfaulkner.myopenid.com
